titleStmt.title: John of Ephesus, Zeʿora, in The Lives of the Eastern Saints
SPEAR: Syriac Persons, Events, and Relations
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

licence.p: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.

sourceDesc.p:
This is a born digital prosopography containing data derived from
The Life of Zeʿora John of Ephesus
The Lives of the Eastern Saints http://syriaca.org/work/9501

event.desc: Za'ura miraculously restored a spring that had stopped flowing

person.persName: The monk who witnessed the miracle performed by Z'ura

personGrp.persName: The persons who gathered together to be blessed by Z'ura

event.desc: The Huns arrived and threatened the holy men, probably in 515.
Za'ura miraculously stopped a Hun from killing him, probably in 515.

personGrp.persName: The mighty hosts of the Huns

person.persName: The Hun barbarian who tried to kill Z'ura

event.desc: Za'ura's master died.
Za'ura made a column for himself and stood on it.
From atop his column Za'ura healed the sick by blessing water and sprinkling it on them.
Chalcedonian persecutors removed Za'ura from his column.
Za'ura took ten disciples and traveled to Constantinople in order to protest the treatment of the non-Chalcedonians to the emperor

personGrp.persName: The ten disciples who followed Z'ura to the royal city

person.persName: The king who was visited by Z'ura

event.desc: The persecutors of Za'ura sent letters to Constantinople to explain their treatment of Za'ura.

The emperor and a group of bishops assemble to oppose Za'ura. Za'ura speaks boldly in defense of his non-Chalcedonian convictions and against the persecution of non-Chalcedonians. The emperor oppossed Za'ura but also feared him.
Za'ura anathematized the Council of Chalcedon and inflicted the emperor with swelling and a compromised mental state.

personGrp.persName: The magistrates who witnessed the encounter between Z'ura and Justinian

event.desc: The empress hid the emperor from all but two physicians and two chamberlains while she convinced Za'ura to heal the emperor.

personGrp.persName: The intercessors who were sent to fetch Z'ura

event.desc: Za'ura restored the emperor to health and the emperor relented from pusuing strict persecution of non-Chalcedonians.
Za'ura's fame grew, extending as far as the city of Rome and enabling him to have great influence among the emperor and the senators. He used this influence to care for the poor.
Pope Agepetus, who was about to blaspheme by declaring that Mary should not be commemorated in the church, urged the emperor to expel Za'ura..

occupation.note: Agapetus was the Patriarch of> Rome

personGrp.persName: The followers of Paul of Samosata

event.desc: Papal and imperial representatives crossed the Golden Horn to Sycae and confronted Za'ura, demanding he obey the emperor. Za'ura refused and they attempted to forcibly bring him into the city but heavy winds prevented their crossing the Golden Horn.
Pope Agepetus dies suddenly on the day predicted by Za'ura and Za'ura's opponents accuse him of using magic against the Pope.

personGrp.persName: The heretics in churches and monasteries who complained against Z'ura

event.desc: Z'ura engaged in affective prayer
Z'ura performed many acts of charity for the poor
Heretics petitioned the king and queen to have Z'ura removed from the city
Z'ura left the city to dwell in the same city as Theodosius
Z'ura died, leaving behind his disciple Hananya
